Battle of the Hydaspes

In 326 BCE, Alexander the Great of Macedon fought a historic battle with King Porus of Paurava on the banks of the river Jhelum (Hydaspes). Although Porus was defeated, his bravery and battlefield skills so impressed Alexander that he not only returned Porus's kingdom but also made him an ally. This battle was an excellent example of Greek strategy against elephants.

ЁЯЫС
Retreat from the Beas

After conquering the Jhelum, Alexander advanced eastward, but his army refused to move further at the river Beas (Hyphasis). Years of continuous warfare, homesickness, and rumors of the vast army of the powerful Nanda Empire in the east (which included thousands of war elephants) demoralized the soldiers. Alexander had to return with a heavy heart.

ЁЯМН
Long-term Impact
  • Political Unification: Alexander crushed the small tribes of the Northwest, creating a power vacuum. Chandragupta Maurya later filled this vacuum and easily conquered the region.
  • Cultural Exchange: This campaign opened direct trade routes between India and Greece. It paved the way for the development of Indo-Greek art (Gandhara style) and numismatics in the future.
  • Historiography: The accounts of Greek historians became important sources for determining the dates of Indian history.
